Question Text: What are some of the reasons that it is difficult to deploy improvements to BGP? Select all that apply.
Choices:
a. Changes are necessarily incremental because of the large installed base of routers that already run BGP.
b. BGP is implemented in hardware, so deploying changes to BGP requires changes on the timescale of hardware development cycles.
c. Deplyoing changes to BGP requires coordination across potentially tens of thousands of ASes in the Internet.
d. Only a few vendors implement BGP, and deploying changes requires convincing those vendors to change the protocol.
e. Deploying changes requires coordination in standards bodies such as the IETF.
LLM Explanation: Deploying improvements to BGP is difficult for several reasons. First, changes need to be incremental due to the large installed base of BGP routers already deployed, making drastic changes infeasible (a). Second, deploying BGP changes requires coordination across the many autonomous systems that make up the Internet, which could number in the tens of thousands (c). Finally, changes to BGP need to go through the standardization process in bodies like the IETF to ensure interoperability (e). BGP is typically implemented in software, not hardware (b), and there are multiple vendors that provide BGP implementations (d), so those are not major factors impeding BGP improvements.
URLs: ['Computer Networking: A Top-Down Approach, 7th Edition by Kurose and Ross, Section 4.3', 'RFC 4271 - A Border Gateway Protocol 4 (BGP-4)', 'https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/about/press/internet-protocol-journal/back-issues/table-contents-35/bgp-deployments.html']

Question Text: Which of the following are true about the RCP? Select all that apply.
Choices:
a. In Phase 1 of RCP deployment, the RCP controller for an AS sees all routes for all destinations that an AS learns from neighboring ASes.
b. In Phase 1 of RCP deployment, there is no need for ASes to use BGP to exchange routes.
c. In an RCP deployment, routers no longer have to compute routes.
d. The RCP controller operates just like a route reflector would, selecting a single best route for each destination for all client routers.
e. In Phase 1 of RCP deployment, a single AS can benefit from deploying RCP even if no other ASes deploy RCP.
LLM Explanation: In Phase 1 of RCP deployment, the RCP controller for an AS sees all routes for all destinations that the AS learns from neighboring ASes (a). The routers in the AS no longer have to compute routes, as this is handled by the RCP controller (c). A single AS can benefit from deploying RCP in Phase 1 even if no other ASes deploy RCP, as it provides benefits within the AS (e). BGP is still needed to exchange routes between ASes in Phase 1 (b is incorrect). The RCP controller does not operate like a route reflector, as it computes and distributes routes to all routers rather than reflecting routes (d is incorrect).
URLs: ['Caesar, M., Caldwell, D., Feamster, N., Rexford, J., Shaikh, A., & van der Merwe, J. (2005). Design and implementation of a routing control platform. Proceedings of the 2nd conference on Symposium on Networked Systems Design & Implementation-Volume 2.', 'Feamster, N., Rexford, J., & Zegura, E. (2013). The road to SDN: an intellectual history of programmable networks. ACM SIGCOMM Computer Communication Review, 44(2), 87-98.']

Question Text: Which of the following are true about network management with BGP, in the absence of RCP? Select all that apply.
Choices:
a. BGP's interaction with the underlying routing IGP routing protocol can result in persistent forwarding loops.
b. Implementing network-wide policy sometimes causes the routers themeselves to have to carry state.
c. Each router operates and makes decisions based only on a local view of network state.
d. BGP routing has a single point of failure.
e. It is not possible to perform traffic engineering with conventional BGP.
LLM Explanation: In the absence of RCP, network management with BGP has the following characteristics:b) Implementing network-wide policy sometimes requires the routers themselves to carry state in order to make consistent routing decisions across the network. c) With BGP, each router operates based on its own local view of the network state obtained through BGP route advertisements from its peers. It does not have a global view of the entire network.Choices a, d and e are incorrect:a) While BGP can have complex interactions with the underlying IGP, it should not result in persistent forwarding loops if configured properly.d) BGP is a distributed routing protocol and does not inherently have a single point of failure. e) Traffic engineering is possible with BGP by using techniques like BGP communities, AS path prepending, local preference, etc.

Question Text: Which of the following is true about the second phase of RCP deployment? Select all that apply.
Choices:
a. The second phase of RCP deployment requires no coordination with neighboring ASes.
b. The second phase of RCP deployment offers potential benefits such as reduced routing table size.
c. In the second phase of deployment, the RCP controller sees all routes for every destination that neighboring ASes advertise.
d. The second phase of deployment requires fewer BGP sessions at the RCP controller than the first phase, thus improving scalability of the controller.
e. In the second phase of RCP deployment, ASes do not need to use BGP to exchange routes with one another.
LLM Explanation: In the second phase of RCP deployment, the RCP controller sees all routes advertised by neighboring ASes for every destination (c). This allows the RCP to select routes on behalf of the AS's routers, reducing the number of routes each router needs to learn and thus reducing routing table size (b). Fewer BGP sessions are required at the RCP controller compared to the first phase, improving controller scalability (d). With the RCP handling route selection, ASes no longer need to use BGP to exchange routes with each other (e). However, the second phase does require coordination with neighboring ASes to establish BGP sessions with the RCP (a is false).
URLs: ['Caesar, M., Caldwell, D., Feamster, N., Rexford, J., Shaikh, A., & van der Merwe, J. (2005). Design and implementation of a routing control platform. Proceedings of the 2nd conference on Symposium on Networked Systems Design & Implementation-Volume 2.', 'Feamster, N., Balakrishnan, H., Rexford, J., Shaikh, A., & Van Der Merwe, J. (2004). The case for separating routing from routers. Proceedings of the ACM SIGCOMM workshop on Future directions in network architecture.']

Question Text: In terms of the parlance of the 4D architecture, which protocol serves as the "dissemination plane" for the RCP?
Choices:
a. External BGP
b. Spanning Tree Protocol
c. The Internal Gateway Protocol (IGP)
d. Internal BGP
e. LLDP
LLM Explanation: In the 4D architecture for Software Defined Networking, the dissemination plane is responsible for distributing network state between the decision plane and the data plane. For the Routing Control Platform (RCP), which is a logically centralized control platform, Internal BGP (iBGP) serves as the dissemination plane protocol. iBGP is used to exchange routing information between the RCP and the individual network devices, allowing the RCP to push forwarding state to the data plane.

Question Text: What are some of the stated goals of simplifying the control plane in the 4D architecture. Select all that apply.
Choices:
a. Improved security.
b. Inherent robustness of control plane
c. Simpler management systems
d. Faster innovation
e. Simpler routers and switches
LLM Explanation: The 4D architecture aims to simplify the control plane to achieve several goals. Improved security (a) is enabled by centralizing control and providing network-wide visibility. Simpler management systems (c) result from decoupling the control logic from the data plane. Faster innovation (d) is possible because the simpler data plane allows control software to evolve independently. Simpler routers and switches (e) are a consequence of moving complex control functions out of the forwarding elements. However, inherent robustness of the control plane (b) is not a stated goal, as the centralized control plane introduces new challenges for robustness that must be addressed.
URLs: ['A. Greenberg et al., "A clean slate 4D approach to network control and management," ACM SIGCOMM Computer Communication Review, vol. 35, no. 5, pp. 41-54, 2005.', 'N. Feamster, J. Rexford, and E. Zegura, "The Road to SDN: An Intellectual History of Programmable Networks," ACM Queue, vol. 11, no. 12, pp. 20-40, 2013.']

Question Text: What are some examples of how a separate decision plane in the 4D architecture can amortize system overhead? Select all that apply.
Choices:
a. Maintaining a single table in memory of AS paths that are learned across all BGP sessions in the AS, and using references into that table for specific routers (and routing decisions), to save memory.
b. If secure BGP were deployed, verifying the signatures on the AS paths of routes received from neighbors.
c. Keeping track of topology information.
d. Performing route computation on behalf of all the routers in the AS.
e. Performing inbound traffic engineering on a set of links in a coordinated fashion.
LLM Explanation: A separate decision plane in the 4D architecture can amortize system overhead in several ways:a) By maintaining a single table of AS paths learned across all BGP sessions and using references to it for specific routers and routing decisions, it can save memory compared to each router maintaining its own full table.  d) The decision plane can perform route computation on behalf of all routers in the AS, reducing duplicated effort.e) It enables coordinated inbound traffic engineering across a set of links, which individual routers cannot easily do.Choices b and c, while valid functions of a decision plane, do not specifically amortize overhead across the system.
URLs: ['A Clean Slate 4D Approach to Network Control and Management, Greenberg et al., 2005', 'https://www.cs.cornell.edu/courses/cs6450/2012sp/papers/4D-ccr05.pdf']

Question Text: What are some examples of network-wide objectives that could be achieved by the decision plane in the 4D architecture? Select all that apply.
Choices:
a. Ensuring that connectivity is not interrupted when a link or router fails
b. Provisioning a BGP peering session to a neighbor AS
c. Balancing traffic load across a network
d. Ensuring predictable behavior for planned maintenance events
e. Counting the volume of video streaming traffic across a peering link
LLM Explanation: In the 4D architecture, the decision plane is responsible for network-wide objectives and management. Some examples that fit this role are:a) Ensuring uninterrupted connectivity during link or router failures, as this requires network-wide coordination and re-routing of traffic.  c) Load balancing traffic across the network to optimize performance and avoid congestion, which needs a global view.d) Ensuring predictable network behavior during planned maintenance by calculating the impact and necessary adjustments across the whole network.The other options are more data plane (forwarding packets, counting traffic) or control plane (BGP peering) functions that operate on individual devices.
URLs: ['Greenberg, Albert, et al. "A clean slate 4D approach to network control and management." ACM SIGCOMM Computer Communication Review 35.5 (2005): 41-54.', 'Casado, Martin, et al. "Ethane: Taking control of the enterprise." Proceedings of the 2007 conference on Applications, technologies, architectures, and protocols for computer communications. 2007.', 'Feamster, Nick, Jennifer Rexford, and Ellen Zegura. "The road to SDN: an intellectual history of programmable networks." ACM SIGCOMM Computer Communication Review 44.2 (2014): 87-98.']

Question Text: Which plane is responsible for installing state into the data plane (e.g., FIB entries, ACLs) in the 4D architecture?
Choices:
a. Discovery plane
b. Data plane
c. Decision plane
d. Dissemination plane
e. None of the above
LLM Explanation: In the 4D architecture, the dissemination plane is responsible for installing state, such as forwarding information base (FIB) entries and access control lists (ACLs), into the data plane elements. The decision plane makes all the control decisions, which are then propagated to the data plane via the dissemination plane.
URLs: ['Greenberg, A., Hjalmtysson, G., Maltz, D. A., Myers, A., Rexford, J., Xie, G., ... & Zhang, H. (2005). A clean slate 4D approach to network control and management. ACM SIGCOMM Computer Communication Review, 35(5), 41-54.', 'Feamster, N., Rexford, J., & Zegura, E. (2013). The road to SDN: an intellectual history of programmable networks. ACM SIGCOMM Computer Communication Review, 44(2), 87-98.']

Question Text: Which plane is responsible for path selection and traffic engineering in the 4D architecture?
Choices:
a. None of the above
b. Discovery plane
c. Decision plane
d. Data plane
e. Dissemination plane
LLM Explanation: In the 4D architecture for Software Defined Networking, the Decision plane is responsible for path selection and traffic engineering. The Decision plane makes decisions on how traffic should flow through the network based on policies and the network topology learned from the Discovery plane.
URLs: ['Gude, N., Koponen, T., Pettit, J., Pfaff, B., Casado, M., McKeown, N., & Shenker, S. (2008). NOX: Towards an operating system for networks. ACM SIGCOMM Computer Communication Review, 38(3), 105-110.', 'Kreutz, D., Ramos, F. M., Verissimo, P. E., Rothenberg, C. E., Azodolmolky, S., & Uhlig, S. (2015). Software-defined networking: A comprehensive survey. Proceedings of the IEEE, 103(1), 14-76.']
